subject: Re: [junit] package suite runner
msgSnippet: ... I ve just finished to develop a new *SuiteBuilder/TestFilter so that getPackageName now returns the exact name of the package without the path.  The code
messageBody:
>> this will include all files ending by "Test" and in the package
>> sun.xyz and
>> subpackages. IIRC SimpleTestFilter.getPackageName returns the path
>> (build/classes/sun.xyz) and not the classpath (sun.xyz). This is clearly
>> something that should be done. But noone complained so far :-)

I've just finished to develop a new *SuiteBuilder/TestFilter so that
getPackageName now returns the exact name of the package without the
path. The code is in CVS so feel free to check it out and build it. It
should be straightforward (you just need some additional jars).
Feedback and beta-testers needed.

> That is nice to hear.. I have around 38 TestXXXSuite classes for the 38
> odd packages.. If this package suite runner is available for all these
> 38 classes would go way..

I normally only have one AllTests.java + several other classes for my
integration tests.

> Already I have eliminated around 4 TestProxy
> classes which were required for testing private methods using the old
> Junitx way of doing.. Instead I have used the PrivateAccesor class of
> JUnit-Add-ons..

Glad to hear that it's used (never used it myself although).

> My directory structure is, each package has sub package *test *under
> which all the tests related to this package are available and build file
> for the project (i.e. the src target responsible for compiling the
> classes) either include these test files when special param build.tests
> is set to true. With this approach all other targets of build.xml remain
> same...

And that's when I say "STOOOOP!" :-) One question: why are your test
less important (or second-class code) than your production code? Simply
compile both your code and your tests at the same time. With Ant it's a
really a no-brainer.

> This means, based on build.test param all the classes would go into same
> destination directory or to the same archive file..

what I normally do:
src/main -> build/classes
src/test -> build/classes-test
src/example -> build/classes-example

I compile all the code, all the time and never had any problems. You
can take a look at JUnit-addons build.xml file if you want.
